body_html:
I agree it's verbose, but it's discoverable (because it's the same function) and I understand what it's doing the first time I see it.

With the new_XXX functions it's not clear what new refers to -- those are just named that way because of the deprecated new function -- someone coming to PyTorch won't understand what new means.

Similarly with,like=...like usually refers to shape / dtype / layout / device -- but I presume here it won't include the shape (if I'm using it with e.g. torch.ones). That's subtle (either if you include it or not), which means I have to read the documentation, internalize it, etc.

body:
I agree it's verbose, but it's discoverable (because it's the same function) and I understand what it's doing the first time I see it.

With the `new_XXX` functions it's not clear what `new` refers to -- those are just named that way because of the deprecated `new` function -- someone coming to PyTorch won't understand what `new` means.

Similarly with,`like=`...like usually refers to shape / dtype / layout / device -- but I presume here it won't include the shape (if I'm using it with e.g. `torch.ones`).  That's subtle (either if you include it or not), which means I have to read the documentation, internalize it, etc.
